Sentence: Launch 'software-updater' (precise and earlier version are called update-manager) and install any updates presented
Launch 'software-updater' (precise and earlier version are called update-manager) and install any updates presented
Verify that the pre-selected time zone is correct or select your time zone and press Enter
Log in and check the desktop is installed
Login and check the system installed correctly
Verify that the pre-selected time zone is correct or select your time zone and press Enter
Log in and check the desktop is installed
Login and check the system installed correctly
Verify that the pre-selected time zone is correct or select your time zone and press Enter
Log in and check the desktop is installed
Login and check the system installed correctly
At "Write changes to disks", verify that everythings is right and select YES
Verify or setup the timezone
From the main menu select Check disk for defectsand press Enter
Check 'Use LVM with the new FAMILY Installation' and 'Encrypt the new FAMILY Installation for security'
Check 'Overwrite empty disk space' and click the 'Install Now' button

If there is only one hard disk, skip to step 14 (On the 'Where are you?' screen...). Otherwise, on the 'Installation type' screen verify that the drive selected on the Select drive list corresponds to the drive on the chart (e.g /dev/sda)
Verify that the full drive space is allocated
Click on the release notes hyperlink to confirm that a browser launches and you are taken to the release notes web page.
Install all updates available for the release you want to upgrade by running update-manager. Click Check if any update is availabe, and click Install to install them
Check that the uname -r returns a -virtual kernel:
Check that the linux-virtual package is installed for the release or the correct hardware enablement stack:
Check with the mount command that virtual disk are mounted read-write
Check that the ubuntu-standard package is not installed:
Check that the size of the kernel modules are below 40M:
Check that the size of the installed system is below 800M:
Boot CD and run the CD self-check (then reboot)
Boot CD and run the CD self-check (then reboot)
Boot CD and run the CD self-check (then reboot)
Check that the uname -r returns a -generic kernel
Check that the linux-virtual package is installed for the release or the correct hardware enablement stack:
Check with the mount command that virtual disk are mounted read-write
Check that the ubuntu-standard package is not installed:
Check that the size of the kernel modules are below 40M:
Check that the size of the installed system is below 800M:
This will then reboot the machine log in and check the desktop is installed
This will then reboot the machine log in and check the desktop is installed
Verify or setup the timezone
At "Write changes to disks", verify that everything is right and select YES
Select 'Yes' to the 'Is the system clock set to UTC?
Once logged in, verify that:
Check dmesg for any abnormal messages or errors.
Check to make sure the architecture is correct for the image you installed:
Select yes or no, depending on your setup (select no if your clock is set to localtime)
On the screen Preparing to install FAMILY, note the state of each check mark for the following components
Open the Terminal pressing CTRL+ALT+T type "lsb_release -r" without the quotes and verify that FAMILY upgraded to the latest release
Check and uncheck the 'Display password' checkbox
Check that / and /home use different partitions
Once your partitioning scheme is laid out click on Install Now
On the screen Preparing to install FAMILY, note the state of each check mark for the following components

Check that the 'test' folder created on the first install has disappeard from the desktop, open Firefox and check that in the history tab has no browsing history, then open a Terminal typing CTRL+ALT+T and type 'df -h' in it without quotes, there should be no /home partition

Check that the 'test' folder created on the first install has disappeard from the desktop, open Firefox and check that in the history tab has no browsing history, then open a Terminal typing CTRL+ALT+T and type 'df -h' in it without quotes, there should be no /home partition
Using the on screen keyboard, enter a few basic commands to sanity check the shell such as 'ls', 'pwd', 'uname -a'
If the on screen keyboard is not present, tap inside the terminal window near where the cursor is blinking

If there is only one hard disk, skip to step 10 (On the 'Where are you?' screen...). Otherwise, on the 'Installation type' screen verify that the drive selected on the Select drive list corresponds to the drive on the chart (e.g /dev/sda)
Verify that the full drive space is allocated
Check the box 'Download updates while installing' if a network is available
If connected, verify that your timezone is proposed correctly
Verify that your pre-upgrade files and installed applications are still present
Find the indicator icon of Chinese Calendar to check whether it autostart
Select Yes or No, depending on your setup (select No if your clock is set to localtime)
Check the configured update time interval for the weather information
Run 'apt-get update' and verify that an ec2 mirror is used.
Start your machine, check the grub options
Log in the system and check the default wallpaper as well as the theme.
Click the button of Dash, enter the application names to check whether they are preinstalled: Chinese Calendar, Weather Indicator, Youker Assistant, Fcitx and Chromium.
Click on the launcher, are all the entries localized?
Click on the entry labeled 'System Settings', are all the entries in the new window that appears localized?
Open the entry marked as 'Locale' in the new window, is the correct language selected in the settings?
Click the tab labeled 'Numbers', is the correct decimal separator chosen for your region?
In the same tab, has the correct Digit set been chosen for your region?
Click the tab labeled 'Money', has the correct currency been chosen for your region?
Click on the tab labeled 'Date & Time', has the correct time format been chosen for your system?
Click on the tab labeled 'Other', has the correct measurement system been chosen for your system?
Click on the 'Overview button to go back to System Settings, and open the entry marked as "Instant Messaging and VOIP", is the UI localized?
Click on the button marked as "Add Account" and complete the process to add a IM account, was entire process localized?
Click on the launcher and then click on the entry marked as "Instant Messenger Contacts" to open your contact list, has the contact list UI been localized?
Close/Minimize all windows, right click on the desktop, is the context menu localized?
Click on the "Default desktop settings" entry, is the new window that appears localized?
Check the box 'Download updates while installing' if a network is available
If connected, verify that your timezone is proposed correctly
Verify that your pre-upgrade files and installed applications are still present

If there is only one hard disk, skip to step 10 (On the 'Where are you?' screen...). Otherwise, on the 'Installation type' screen verify that the drive selected on the Select drive list corresponds to the drive on the chart (e.g /dev/sda)
Verify that the full drive space is allocated
Is this time zone correct?
Write changes to disks, verify targets, if correct, to start
How do you want to manage upgrades on this system?
Verify Internet access: sudo apt-get update
Verify access to tasksel: sudo tasksel

If there is only one hard disk, skip to step 10 (On the 'Where are you?' screen...). Otherwise, on the 'Installation type' screen verify that the drive selected on the Select drive list corresponds to the drive on the chart (e.g /dev/sda)

Login and check the system installed correctly
Check output of free -h

Perform a large (300-600MB) file copy to USB storage Generate a large (500MB) file: dd if=/dev/urandom of=rubbish bs=1M count=500Insert a USB stick (appropriately sized) into a spare USB portMake a mount directory: sudo mkdir /mnt/stickMount the stick: sudo mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/stick(modify mount-point as necessary; check sudo dmesgoutput if unsure)Copy the file: sudo cp rubbish /mnt/stick/Unmount the stick: sudo umount /mnt/stickRemove the stick from the USB portRe-insert the stick into the USB portRe-mount the stick: sudo mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/stick(again, adjust mount-point as necessary)Compare the copied file to that on the stick: cmp rubbish /mnt/stick/rubbish

With an HDMI monitor that supports audio plugged into the HDMI0 output, and an available MP3 file: Install mpg321 and amixer with sudo apt install mpg321 alsa-utilsFind the correct hardware output for the HDMI0 port: cat /proc/asound/cardsand note the number at the start of the line for the HDMI0 port (usually 0 and possibly 1 for any connected monitor(s), and 1 or possibly 2 for the headphone jack)Attempt to play your MP3 file with: mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:,0 substituting for the number found during the previous step, and for your choice of MP3 file, e.g. mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:0,0 "Jeff Wayne - War of the Worlds.mp3"Use Ctrl+Cto end playback early, if you wishIf you cannot hear anything, first check that the mixer's volume is not set too low; run alsamixer, and adjust the volume (Jfor down, Kfor up) before exiting (Esc) and retrying playback

With an HDMI monitor that supports audio plugged into the HDMI1 output, and an available MP3 file: Install mpg321 and amixer with sudo apt install mpg321 alsa-utilsFind the correct hardware output for the HDMI1 port: cat /proc/asound/cardsand note the number at the start of the line for the HDMI1 port (usually 0 and possibly 1 for any connected monitor(s), and 1 or possibly 2 for the headphone jack)Attempt to play your MP3 file with: mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:,0 substituting for the number found during the previous step, and for your choice of MP3 file, e.g. mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:0,0 "Jeff Wayne - War of the Worlds.mp3"Use Ctrl+Cto end playback early, if you wishIf you cannot hear anything, first check that the mixer's volume is not set too low; run alsamixer, and adjust the volume (Jfor down, Kfor up) before exiting (Esc) and retrying playback

With a pair of headphones with a 3.5mm jack, and an available MP3 file: Install mpg321 and amixer with sudo apt install mpg321 alsa-utilsFind the correct hardware output for the headphone jack: cat /proc/asound/cardsand note the number at the start of the line for the headphone jack (usually 0 and possibly 1 for any connected monitor(s), and 1 or possibly 2 for the headphone jack)Attempt to play your MP3 file with: mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:,0 substituting for the number found during the previous step, and for your choice of MP3 file, e.g. mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:0,0 "Jeff Wayne - War of the Worlds.mp3"Use Ctrl+Cto end playback early, if you wishIf you cannot hear anything, first check that the mixer's volume is not set too low; run alsamixer, and adjust the volume (Jfor down, Kfor up) before exiting (Esc) and retrying playback
Check auto-configuration of ethernet Run ip addrCheck that a valid IP address is recorded on the eth0 interfaceCheck ping google.comsuccessfully pings a few times (Ctrl+Cto cancel)

Configure wifi via netplan Place the following in /etc/netplan/wifi.yaml(substituting the SSID and password as necessary):network: version: 2 wifis: wlan0: dhcp4: true access-points: my-ssid-here: password: my-password-hereRun sudo netplan applyWait a few seconds (to allow DHCP to complete), then run ip addrCheck that a valid IP address is recorded on the wlan0 interfaceCheck ping google.comsuccessfully pings a few times (Ctrl+Cto cancel)
Check 'Erase disk and use ZFS'

Open a terminal, run the following commands and verify their output (the output depends on your hardware)

Perform a large (300-600MB) file copy to USB storage Generate a large (500MB) file: dd if=/dev/urandom of=rubbish bs=1M count=500Insert a USB stick (appropriately sized) into a spare USB portMake a mount directory: sudo mkdir /mnt/stickMount the stick: sudo mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/stick(modify mount-point as necessary; check sudo dmesgoutput if unsure)Copy the file: sudo cp rubbish /mnt/stick/Unmount the stick: sudo umount /mnt/stickRemove the stick from the USB portRe-insert the stick into the USB portRe-mount the stick: sudo mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/stick(again, adjust mount-point as necessary)Compare the copied file to that on the stick: cmp rubbish /mnt/stick/rubbish

With an HDMI monitor that supports audio, and an available MP3 file: Install mpg321 and amixer with sudo apt install mpg321 alsa-utilsFind the correct hardware output for the HDMI port: cat /proc/asound/cardsand note the number at the start of the line for the HDMI port (usually 0 and possibly 1 for any connected monitor(s), and 1 or possibly 2 for the headphone jack)Attempt to play your MP3 file with: mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:,0 substituting for the number found during the previous step, and for your choice of MP3 file, e.g. mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:0,0 "Jeff Wayne - War of the Worlds.mp3"Use Ctrl+Cto end playback early, if you wishIf you cannot hear anything, first check that the mixer's volume is not set too low; run alsamixer, and adjust the volume (Jfor down, Kfor up) before exiting (Esc) and retrying playback

With a pair of headphones with a 3.5mm jack, and an available MP3 file: Install mpg321 and amixer with sudo apt install mpg321 alsa-utilsFind the correct hardware output for the headphone jack: cat /proc/asound/cardsand note the number at the start of the line for the headphone jack (usually 0 and possibly 1 for any connected monitor(s), and 1 or possibly 2 for the headphone jack)Attempt to play your MP3 file with: mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:,0 substituting for the number found during the previous step, and for your choice of MP3 file, e.g. mpg321 -o alsa -a hw:0,0 "Jeff Wayne - War of the Worlds.mp3"Use Ctrl+Cto end playback early, if you wishIf you cannot hear anything, first check that the mixer's volume is not set too low; run alsamixer, and adjust the volume (Jfor down, Kfor up) before exiting (Esc) and retrying playback

Configure wifi via netplan Place the following in /etc/netplan/wifi.yaml(substituting the SSID and password as necessary):network: version: 2 wifis: wlan0: dhcp4: true access-points: my-ssid-here: password: my-password-hereRun sudo netplan applyWait a few seconds (to allow DHCP to complete), then run ip addrCheck that a valid IP address is recorded on the wlan0 interfaceCheck ping google.comsuccessfully pings a few times (Ctrl+Cto cancel)

Note the state of the 'Check Erase Disk and install FAMILY' radio button

Verify that the full drive space is allocated
Verify that neither the restricted nor multiverse archives have been enabled by typing grep "restricted\|multiverse" /etc/apt/sources.list | grep -v "^#"
Verify that the linux-restricted-modules package has not been installed by typing dpkg -l linux-restricted-* | grep -vE "^[a-z]n"
Check your keyboard layout is correct or alter
Select country either by typing in the name of the country or city or timezone (WARNING: time zones are not read by the screen-reader; the default should be fine)
Select country either by typing in the name of the country or city or timezone (WARNING: time zones are not read by the screen-reader; the default should be fine)

If there is only one hard disk, skip to step 10 (On the 'Where are you?' screen...). Otherwise, on the 'Installation type' screen verify that the drive selected on the Select drive list corresponds to the drive on the chart (e.g /dev/sda)
